com.oceanoptics.omnidriver.features.i2cbus

Interface I2CBus


  • public interface I2CBus
    This interface provides access to the I2C bus that is connected to a device. I2C provides a means of sending and receiving small packets of bytes in a serial manner with a 400Khz clock.

    Intended devices are HR4000, USB2000, QE65000, USB2000+, HR4000+, HR2000, HR2000+, and USB4000.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      byte[] getI2CBytes(byte address, byte numBytes)
      Performs a general purpose read on the I2C pins for interfacing to attached peripherals.
      int setI2CBytes(byte address, byte numBytes, byte[] i2C)
      Performs a general-purpose write on the I2C pins for interfacing to attached peripherals.

    • Method Detail

      • setI2CBytes

        int setI2CBytes(byte address,
                byte numBytes,
                byte[] i2C)
         throws java.io.IOException
        Performs a general-purpose write on the I2C pins for interfacing to attached peripherals. The time to complete the command is determined by the amount of data transferred and the response time of the peripheral. The I2C bus runs at 400KHz.
        Parameters:
        address - The I2C address of the attached peripheral
        numBytes - The number of bytes that will be transferred to the peripheral (max is 61)
        i2C - A byte array containing the data to be written to the I2C peripheral
        Returns:
        The result of the write to the I2C.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - is thrown if the command cannot be sent to the device.

      • getI2CBytes

        byte[] getI2CBytes(byte address,
                   byte numBytes)
            throws java.io.IOException
        Performs a general purpose read on the I2C pins for interfacing to attached peripherals. The time to complete the command is determined by the amount of data transferred and the response time of the peripheral. The I2C bus runs at 400KHz. The maximum number of bytes that can be read is 61.
        Parameters:
        address - The I2C address of the attached peripheral
        numBytes - The number of bytes that will be transferred from the peripheral (max is 61)
        Returns:
        Array of bytes containing the read data. May be null.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - is thrown if the device is unable to read from the bus.
